callum-gleeson-voice-battle.title:
Callum Gleeson performs in ‘Battle
Round’ of ‘The Voice’
callum-gleeson-voice-battle.abstract:
Former Rushworth resident Callum Gleeson has shown his talent in the final ‘Battle Round’ of ‘The Voice’, the very popular talent
quest on Channel 9. The program went to air on Monday 29 June.

pars:
Former Rushworth resident Callum Gleeson has shown his talent in the final ‘Battle Round’ of ‘The Voice’, the very popular talent
quest on Channel 9. The program went to air on Monday 29 June.

His coach Delta Goodrem partnered him
with twelve year old Emmagen Rain and they
sang ‘Footloose’ by Kenny Loggins. The
atmosphere was electric and the audience
loved their performance.

The feedback from the judges was
positive, but it was up to Delta Goodrem, the
coach of both performers, to select whether
Callum or Emmagen proceeded to the ‘Play-
Off’ rounds.

Delta chose Emmagen because she felt
she could mould her to what she wanted to
be, whereas Callum is already an established
artist. The ‘Play-Off’ rounds will be screened
on Channel 9 this coming Sunday, Monday
and Tuesday evenings.

When asked by the Waranga News
reporter about his reaction, Callum said, ‘To
get to this point in ‘The Voice’ was a pinnacle
of my career. I’ve had tremendous support
from my fans and friends, and especially
from my family.”

“People can connect
with me on my professional
Facebook page - just type
in my name. I will be doing
livestream concerts during
the COVID-19 lockdown at
3:30 pm every Saturday and
I would love people to make
requests and join in the fun,”
he added.
CDs available

All of Callum’s six CDs,
including ‘Callum Gleeson
– the Nashville Album’
recorded in Nashville,
USA, in June this year, are available for
purchase at Focus Cards & Gifts in the
Mall at Shepparton, High Street Vacuums
and Electrical in Shepparton, ONE FM, the
Wunghnu Tavern and at any of Callum’s gigs.

Each Thursday from 12 midday to 3pm
Callum presents his popular program on 98.5
ONE FM, the community radio station in
Shepparton.

made-road-wetland.title: “Made road” wetland in Rushy
made-road-wetland.abstract:
This is Pyle Road, Rushworth, normally a winding gravelled road linking the western edge of Rushworth township
with many of the grain and grazing properties around Moora. When it rains, however, Pyle Road becomes an
impassable quagmire trapping any unwary motorist who chooses to plumb its depths!

pars:
This is Pyle Road, Rushworth, normally a winding gravelled road linking the western edge of Rushworth township
with many of the grain and grazing properties around Moora. When it rains, however, Pyle Road becomes an
impassable quagmire trapping any unwary motorist who chooses to plumb its depths!

Numerous vehicles use Pyle Road on a
daily basis, as local residents make their
way to and from work. At weekends, the
surrounding bush is a mecca for itinerant
prospectors trying their luck with their latest
gold detector.

Needless to say, Pyle Road is not the only
local thoroughfare with surface “blemishes”,
and with road bitumenising a mere pipedream
in many parts of northern Victoria, this
situation is likely to persist.

One consolation, however, is that few
roads around Echuca or other regional towns
can boast Rushworth’s variety of local native
orchids, which are now beginning their annual
journey towards flowering and reproduction
in the forest adjacent to Pyle Road.

callum-gleeson-stars.title:
Callum Gleeson stars
on ‘The Voice’
callum-gleeson-stars.abstract:
A very popular talent show is Channel 9’s ‘The Voice’ and on
Monday 9 June former Rushworth resident Callum Gleeson
starred.

pars:
A very popular talent show is Channel 9’s ‘The Voice’ and on
Monday 9 June former Rushworth resident Callum Gleeson
starred.

Callum, the son of Noel (a former policeman at Rushworth) and
Bev, is a well known entertainer and showcased his skills in this
television performance.

In the third last of the Blind Auditions, with the four coaches,
Guy Sebastian, Delta Goodrem, Boy George and Kelly Rowland
close to having their teams full, it was not easy to get them to turn
their chairs.

Callum sang ‘Locomotion’ and very positively engaged the large
audience present and it was very rewarding for him when Delta
Goodrem turned her chair and later complimented him for having ‘a
beautiful voice’. Delta will now be his coach in the ‘Battle Rounds’.

While on screen, Callum publicly thanked ‘my wonderful
supportive family who have been with me all along.’

Watching Callum off stage (but still featured on the television
screen) were his parents, his brother Tyson and the family’s two
poodles that the production team had asked them to bring. (When not
singing, Callum loves to show his family’s poodles at dog shows).
After his performance, a coach invited his mother to bring one of the
poodles onto the stage and the coaches and the audience loved the
beautiful dog.
Callum doesn’t know when he will be next on ‘The Voice’.

pars:
Unfortunately COVID-19 has brought his career as an entertainer

fonterra-support-community.title:
Fonterra teams up to support
community groups in northern Victoria
fonterra-support-community.abstract:
While we might be in the midst of winter, the local community will be able to make a splash this summer after the Stanhope Community
Pool received funding from Fonterra’s Grass Roots Fund to help keep the pool running.

pars:
While we might be in the midst of winter, the local community will be able to make a splash this summer after the Stanhope Community
Pool received funding from Fonterra’s Grass Roots Fund to help keep the pool running.

The pool is one of six
community groups across
northern Victoria to receive
support from Fonterra this week,
with other initiatives ranging
from fire safety equipment and
community gardens to sporting
equipment and swimming
programs.

Fonterra Regional Operations
Manager Steve Taylor said
Fonterra was pleased to once
again be supporting local
community groups across
northern Victoria.

“We’ve partnered with the
Stanhope Community Pool for the
past four years because we know
that this facility plays a crucial
role in bringing communities
together,” Mr Taylor said.

“It’s a hub for families during
the summer, it gets a lot of use
and we know how important it is
to our community.

“It’s a partnership that is
important to us and our local
community.”

Stanhope Pool Committee
Secretary Michelle Ponton said
the swimming pool had been
part of the Stanhope community
for more than 70 years and was
a hive of activity in the summer
months.

“We have more than 2000
people walk through our gates
during the summer period. It’s a
place where families can come
and enjoy time together,” Ms
Ponton said.

“The support from Fonterra
means we can cover the day-today
running expenses of the pool
and ensure it stays open for the
community. It also means we
can run our school swimming
program for students from
Stanhope Primary School.

“It’s our job to provide a safe
place for people to swim, stay
active, and enjoy – thanks to
Fonterra we are able to do this.”

Mr Taylor said Fonterra’s
community sponsorship
program is changing next year
so it can further support its local
community.

“The team is currently
working through these changes
and will be able to share more
information on this later in the
year – so keep your eyes peeled,”
he said.

The other northern Victorian
recipients of Fonterra’s Grass
Roots Fund for 2020 include:

• Leitchville Gunbower Football Netball Club
  • Kyabram Fauna Park
  • Stanhope Fire Brigade
  • Stanhope Primary School Parents Club
  • Stanhope Bowls Club

colbo-on-silo-art-trail.title: Colbo takes its place on the silo art trail
colbo-on-silo-art-trail.abstract:
The Colbinabbin Silo Art Project Artist painting of the mural has now
been finalised. Artist Tim Bowtell departed from town on Monday 25 May
after twelve weeks of painting an outstanding art mural of Colbinabbin’s
History on the six Vic Feeds silos.

pars:
The Colbinabbin Silo Art Project Artist painting of the mural has now
been finalised. Artist Tim Bowtell departed from town on Monday 25 May
after twelve weeks of painting an outstanding art mural of Colbinabbin’s
History on the six Vic Feeds silos.

Tim and his son Jake concluded the art work, providing a clear coat
finish over the entire art works to protect the design for everyone to enjoy
for many years.

The Colbinabbin community has enjoyed watching Tim transform the
art canvas on their many daily visits. Thanks to Tim and his support
crew for completing the fantastic art designs which are already attracting
visitors to Colbo.
Next Steps

The Colbinabbin community now needs to take care of the art work,
maintain the surrounds and in partnership with the Colbinabbin &
District Historical Society Inc will now move to further develop the
viewing area by expanding the parking space and creating parklands and
picnic areas - so stay tuned!

push-for-rail-trail.title: Renewed push for Rail Trail
push-for-rail-trail.abstract:
The much anticipated walking and cycling trail planned between Rushworth Murchison has once again attracted a new burst of
enthusiasm amongst Rushworth residents and the creation of a ‘Rushworth Rail Trail Friends’ Facebook group.

pars:
The much anticipated walking and cycling trail planned between Rushworth Murchison has once again attracted a new burst of
enthusiasm amongst Rushworth residents and the creation of a ‘Rushworth Rail Trail Friends’ Facebook group.
Long term project

The rail trail project has been on the agenda
since a public meeting held in Rushworth in
2007, at which 80 people attended to hear
proposals for the disused railway corridor.

In 2009 Waranga News reported that
the Shire of Campaspe was successful in its
application, to control the lease of the railway
land on which the Rushworth – Murchison
Rail trail will be constructed. Victrack was
responsible for the leasing of railway land in
Victoria.

It was noted then that in the two years
since the original idea was suggested,
extensive engineering reports had been made
using an Engineer appointed by the shire for
that purpose.

Over following years a number of
negotiations with VicTrack, DELWP, Parks
Victoria and other bodies ensued, as well as
feasibility studies and cost analyses for the
project.

In 2016 Campaspe Council endorsed
the signing of land management agreements
in order to progress external funding
negotiations.

While the proposed Waranga Trail included
the rail trail from Murchison to Rushworth and a
connecting trail through to Heathcote, separate
scoping and estimates for each section were
carried out. An interim costing at the time
predicted the Rushworth to Murchison link
would cost approximately $1.2 million.
Local action

Rushworth resident Graeme Hanigan
recently created the Facebook group
‘Rushworth Rail Trail Friends’ in response to
a post asking about the project.

“In the space of just one week it has
gained 180 members, which in my experience
with Facebook groups is quite remarkable
and I believe reveals a genuine need within
the community,” Mr Hanigan said.

Followers of the page were encouraged
to make a submission supporting the rail
trail project to the to the Shire’s draft budge
process which closed last Friday.

The Waranga Trail was identified as a key
Shire of Campaspe project in the Regional
Development Australia prospectus.

• To transform the disused railway land into a multifunctional trail.
  • To develop an important environmental corridor which will benefit our precious and unique native flora and fauna.
  • To increase awareness regarding the flora and fauna of the district, including the vulnerability of many of the species within the box ironbark forest.
  • To provide educational opportunities.
  • To revegetate the trail, which will not only prevent erosion and therefore improve runoff water quality, but it will also enhance the Basin foreshore and views.
  • To provide information on historical areas of significance along the trail.
  • To create a safe alternative route between Murchison and Rushworth that can be utilised by both pedestrians and cyclists alike.
  • To improve the health of the general population who will benefit by using the trail.
  • To provide economic benefit to the local community.

murchison-historical-society-still-activ.title: Work goes on for Murchison & District Historical Society!
murchison-historical-society-still-activ.abstract:
Murchison & District Historical Society is still active behind the scenes during ‘lockdown’ and closure of the Heritage Centre, with
various projects continuing by members working from home.

pars:
Murchison & District Historical Society is still active behind the scenes during ‘lockdown’ and closure of the Heritage Centre, with
various projects continuing by members working from home.

We have had contacts from
people who have now found
the time to follow up on family
history, others wanting details
of local properties and others
reviving memories of time spent
in Murchison some years ago.
One such person is John Taylor, a
trainee surveyor employed by the
State Rivers and Water Supply
Commission in 1953 who was
involved with the building of the
Cattanach Canal and who was
billeted in the abandoned POW
Camp 13 Murchison.

John has sent some great
photographs of the Bucyrus-Erie
walking dragline (commonly
referred to as “Monaghan”).
This enormous machine replaced
the heavy work previously
performed by horses dragging a
single bucket and human labour
at the time of the construction
of the Stuart Murray Canal in
the 1890’s. Monaghan, which
was fitted with a 30m boom,
a 5.7m³ bucket, and a 385 HP
diesel motor, was able to move a
massive 7,186m³ of soil per hour.
Monaghan was imported entirely
from USA, and was assembled
on-site in Murchison. A total of
4,500,000m³ of soil was removed
during its two years on the Canal.

This mechanisation meant
a more direct course to the
Waranga Basin was possible,
compared to the early days
when building the Stuart Murray
Canal. Then, any elevated terrain
was avoided that would entail
massive excavation, resulting in a
circuitous, meandering and much
longer route whereas the walking
dragline with its huge bucket,
ploughed straight through hills in
its path thus creating the shorter,
straighter Cattanach Canal.

The ‘Big Cut’ is a rarelyseen
section of the Cattanach
Canal where the channel cut
through a rise just before the
Canal enters the Waranga
Basin. Here the depth of cut
is the greatest on the Canal, up
to 19m, resulting in impressive
steep cliff-like walls.
Kay Ball, President, Murchison & District Historical Society

a-new-look-for-stanhope.title: A New Look Business Centre for Stanhope
a-new-look-for-stanhope.abstract: During the COVID lockdown the Stanhope Business Centre has received a complete new facelift.

pars: During the COVID lockdown the Stanhope Business Centre has received a complete new facelift.

Firstly it was given a new paint job, with
a changed colour scheme of light grey and
a dark grey for the trims, with the windows
remaining white.

According to the Business Centre
managers and the Stanhope & District
Development Committee Inc (S&DDC),
local feedback received has been one hundred
percent positive.

Recently, a historic mural has been
attached to the Monash Street side wall.
This mural is created from very old photos
gathered by the S&DDC from a variety of
sources, depicting the very early history
of Stanhope. It records the time following
the breaking up of the huge Winter-Irving
Estate, the formation of the Closer Settlement
Scheme by the Government and later,
following the First World War, the Soldier
Settlement Scheme.

They also show the very early formation
of the Stanhope & District Dairy Co operative
on the same site and the forerunner of today’s
Fonterra. These are displayed together with
an early photo of the Stanhope railway station
and a photo of the disastrous fire, which
destroyed most of the businesses on the south
side of Birdwood Avenue in the 1920s.

These photos and the stories that
accompany them, were gathered mainly by
Glenda Cowie, President of the S&DDC and
other members of the committee.

The photos were transposed by Karl
Devlin, of Karl Devlin Signs, onto aluminium
and attached to the wall for all to see.

All this was made possible in part, by a
grant received by the S&DDC from FRRR.

perfect-place-to-excercise.title: A perfect place to exercise
perfect-place-to-excercise.abstract:
As COVID-19 restrictions are gradually eased, many people are seeking new places to explore while exercising.
One such place is literally on Rushworth’s door-step .... its spectacular nine hole sand green Golf Course nestled
between the Old and New Rushworth-Tatura Roads and liberally enhanced with native flora and fauna.

pars:
As COVID-19 restrictions are gradually eased, many people are seeking new places to explore while exercising.
One such place is literally on Rushworth’s door-step .... its spectacular nine hole sand green Golf Course nestled
between the Old and New Rushworth-Tatura Roads and liberally enhanced with native flora and fauna.

Following higher than normal rainfalls in
late 2019 and during the first few months of
this year, the Course is resplendent in diverse
shades of green.

Rushworth Golf Club President Denis
Hardie says that the Club encourages
members of the public to enjoy the Course for
exercise, pet walking and bush exploration
while enjoying the fresh air in a delightful
setting.

The best access to the Course is via the
Clubhouse carpark in Tatura Road, where
there is ample parking. Social distancing will
still be required, and visitors are asked to help
maintain the Course’s immaculate appearance
by sensible and sensitive use of the grounds.

So if the opportunity presents, enjoy
the Rushworth Golf Course and its many
attractions - we know you’ll enjoy it!
(Call Denis on 0422156285 for more information.)

creating-writing-course.title: Creative Writing course to start on 1 June
creating-writing-course.abstract:
In the last edition of the Waranga News, Rushworth Community House advised readers that it was planning to deliver
a Creative Writing course over the coming weeks and several people have already expressed an interest in joining the
program. The course will be going ahead, but with a few changes that should make it even better!

pars:
In the last edition of the Waranga News, Rushworth Community House advised readers that it was planning to deliver
a Creative Writing course over the coming weeks and several people have already expressed an interest in joining the
program. The course will be going ahead, but with a few changes that should make it even better!

Teacher and published author John
Kriesfeld will run the course over eight weeks
beginning on Monday, 1 June. Sessions start at
6.30pm and finish around 8pm.

With the easing of COVID-19 restrictions,
it was decided to run the course “face-to-face”
in the Community House’s large multipurpose
room, where up to six students and the course
leader can be accommodated using social
distancing guidelines.

The course will cover all of the important
elements of creative writing using prepared
notes, workshopping, developmental exercises
and homework, and is designed to enhance
each student’s individual writing style.

Whether they plan to write a professional
personal CV or a major work of fact or fiction,
students will benefit from the course.

At just $80 for the entire eight weeks, it’s
genuine value for money. Who knows, you
might soon join the irrepressable Ian Rogerson
(pictured at right) at the Waranga News and create some magical tales for people of all ages
to enjoy. Please call Rushworth Community
House on 5856 1295 to book a place on this
exciting new local initiative.

1. Always avoid annoying alliteration!
  2. Don’t succumb to redundant-type redundancy or use more words than necessary as it is quite superflfluous.
  3. Always be more or less specifific.
  4. A preposition is not a thing to end a sentence with.
  5. Avoid cliches like the plague - after all is said and done, they’re old hat.
  6. Comparisons are as bad as cliches!
  7. Rhetorical questions! Who needs ‘em?
  8. You’s the write won when words sound a like.
  9. Exaggeration is billions of times worse than understatement.

excellent-quality-wines.title: Heathcote region producing excellent quality wine this year
excellent-quality-wines.abstract:
As vintage 2020 comes to a close,
winemakers and grape growers around
the country are taking stock of what was
a particularly challenging vintage. But the
news is not all bad for local wine lovers.

pars:
As vintage 2020 comes to a close,
winemakers and grape growers around
the country are taking stock of what was
a particularly challenging vintage. But the
news is not all bad for local wine lovers.

With COVID-19 occupying the news over
the last couple of months, it’s easy to forget the
events that shaped our summer. The Australian
wine industry was particularly exposed to the
challenges posed by dry conditions, bushfires
and finally the COVID-19 pandemic.

The growing season started with dry
conditions, due to a lower than average
rainfall over winter. None the less, the vines
began their march toward harvest with bud
burst occurring in early spring.

In late November, hot windy weather
coincided with flowering in some grape
growing regions of south-eastern Australia.
The hot conditions resulted in a reduction
in the number of flowers that set fruit on the
vine, reducing the yield potential of some
varieties. The weather was very warm in
December, however it moderated in January,
allowing vines to grow well and establish a
healthy canopy.

Meanwhile, the bushfires in New South
Wales, South Australia and Victoria grew
in size and burnt larges areas of each state.
The fires sadly destroyed some vineyards,
while many others were indirectly affected
by smoke taint. Smoke taint occurs when
ripening grapes are bathed in fresh smoke for
a period of time. Compounds from the smoke
are absorbed into the skin of the grape, which
can be transferred to the wine during the
winemaking process.
Not affected by smoke taint

Thankfully, testing of grapes prior to
harvest at the Australian Wine Research
Institute laboratory showed that grapes from
the Heathcote wine region were not affected
by smoke taint.

“We feel grateful because some growers
in the Hunter Valley and other regions
adjacent to the fires chose not to harvest at all
this year,” said Gerard Kennedy of Kennedy
Vintners.

Finally, in the middle of vintage, Australia
went into lockdown due to the COVID-19
pandemic. This dealt the industry another
blow because of its reliance on the hospitality
industry and cellar doors to sell the majority
of our wine.

While it has been a challenging vintage
for Heathcote producers, this year’s wines
are developing to be of excellent quality,
with intense colour and flavour. This is a
very positive and welcome end to an eventful
vintage 2020.

If you are looking to purchase wine,
please consider supporting one of the many
small businesses located in the Heathcote
wine region. Many wineries have online
stores and will ship directly to your door.

kennedyvintners-special-offer.title:
Special offer for Waranga
News readers

pars:

time-to-celebrate.title: Time to celebrate our Nurses
time-to-celebrate.abstract: On 12 May each year International Nurses Day is celebrated globally on the birthday of Florence Nightingale, the founder of modern nursing.

pars: On 12 May each year International Nurses Day is celebrated globally on the birthday of Florence Nightingale, the founder of modern nursing.

There surely couldn’t be a more appropriate time to celebrate the work of our nurses than in the middle of a health crisis such as
we are experiencing at present. Pictured are some of our local nurses: Lynn Cruz, Beth Parker, Amy Francis and Amanda Williams
from the Waranga Medical Centre.

The central role nurses and midwives
have in the delivery of care to communities
across the globe has been recognised by the
World Health Organisation (WHO) declaring
2020 the ‘Year of the Nurse and Midwife’.

This also coincides with the 200th
anniversary of the birth of Florence
Nightingale. We celebrate and acknowledge
the invaluable contributions nurses make to
health care and improving outcomes for all.

As the single largest workforce group,
nurses are there at every turn, making a real
difference to the care and the experience of
patients and their families and carers.

We acknowledge the compassion,
professionalism, and commitment of nurses
caring for patients in our community and
celebrate and appreciate nurses, for their
important role of nursing across the world.
Thank you nurses!

financial-support.title:
Financial support measures
endorsed to support community
financial-support.abstract:
Campaspe Shire Council has endorsed a range of financial support measures to assist
ratepayers, residents, businesses and community groups in response to the coronavirus
pandemic.

pars:
Campaspe Shire Council has endorsed a range of financial support measures to assist
ratepayers, residents, businesses and community groups in response to the coronavirus
pandemic.

Mayor, Cr Adrian Weston said the
measures are aimed at supporting individuals
and groups experiencing difficulty in paying
a range of Council charges such as rates,
accounts, rents, as well as suspending debt
collection or enforcement action.

“We acknowledge there are still many
unknowns at the moment, particularly
around the length of time the impacts will be
experienced to control and manage the spread
of coronavirus,” Cr Weston said.

“Also each person’s circumstance is
different and while we have endorsed a range
of measures, I would encourage individuals
or groups who feel the measures do not
support their specific circumstance to make
contact as soon as possible.”

A summary of the financial support
measures are:

• Rate payments
  • EWMAC
  • Animal registrations
  • Library fees
  • Hire fees
  • Rental payments – Council owned commercial properties
  • Rental payments – Council owned

Supporting payment plans to address
individual needs; waiving interest for the
period from 25 March to 30 September 2020;
and suspending any debt collection processes
until 30 September 2020.

Pausing direct debits for the Echuca War
Memorial Aquatic Centre until the centre
reopens; extension of prepaid memberships
to honour the number of months impacted or,
on request, offer a pro-rata refund from 23
March 2020.

Deferring enforcement action on unpaid
registrations until 30 September 2020.

Waiving library fees from Monday, 23
March 2020 for any non-returned materials
until one month after the library service
returns to full operation.

Refunding all fees paid in advance to
hire Council facilities, including the Echuca
Wharf and recreation reserves, where an
event has been cancelled as a result of the
pandemic.

Waiving monthly commercial property
rental payments for businesses or community
groups impacted by the State Government
Restricted Activities direction, occupying
Council buildings and facilities by lease or
licence, from Monday, 23 March 2020 for
three months, then on a month by month
basis until the direction to remain closed is
revoked.

Waiving rental payments for businesses,
artisans or community groups impacted by
the State Government Restricted Activities
direction, occupying Council buildings and
facilities by lease or licence in line with
Council’s Leases for Community Groups Waiving rental payments for businesses,
artisans or community groups impacted by
the State Government Restricted Activities
direction, occupying Council buildings and
facilities by lease or licence in line with
Council’s Leases for Community Groups Artisans Policy, on a pro rata basis for
three months, then on a month by month
basis until the direction to remain closed is
revoked.

Deferring payments for community
groups impacted by the State Government
Restricted Activities direction occupying
Council buildings and facilities by a User
Agreement until 30 September 2020.

Agreeing to surrender any lease or licence,
if a business or community group gives
notice, without penalty until 30 September
2020, except when there is an outstanding
debt prior to 23 March.

Suspending debt collection processes
until 30 September 2020.

Waiving the 14 day notice period for the
cancellation of any child care attendance at
Council operated child care centres from 23
March.

Waiving, on a monthly pro rata basis, fees
related to the 2020/21 public spaces trading
permits for the display of goods, A-frames
and footpath trading, if businesses have been
impacted by the State Government Restricted
Activities direction, until the direction is
revoked.

“The financial implications of these
measures to Council have not been quantified
at this stage, however impacts that extend
into the 2020/21 financial year will be
captured when a revised budget is developed
and can be more precisely quantified,” the
Mayor added.

“We are acutely aware that the recovery of
communities and the local economy will need
to be our paramount focus when restrictions
are eased.”

Council will now write to businesses and
community groups set to benefit from these
financial support measures outlining how
these support measures will be applied.
More detail about the financial support measures will also be made available on Council’s website, www.campaspe.vic.gov.au/covidfinance.

anzac-day-commemoration-2020.title: 2020 Anzac Day commemoration via live streaming and online
anzac-day-commemoration-2020.abstract:
This year Anzac Day 2020 will be commemorated in a very different way, as coming together as community becomes both a memory
and a future aspiration. While the traditional Dawn Service and veterans’ marches will not take place this year, Australians are being
invited to mark the day in a number of safe and special ways.

pars:
This year Anzac Day 2020 will be commemorated in a very different way, as coming together as community becomes both a memory
and a future aspiration. While the traditional Dawn Service and veterans’ marches will not take place this year, Australians are being
invited to mark the day in a number of safe and special ways.

As every year, no matter where you may
be, you can follow Anzac Day services and
ceremonies on the ABC.

To acknowledge the sacrifices of our
servicemen and women, a nationally
broadcast commemorative service will take
place at the Australian War Memorial on the
morning of Anzac Day, 25 April. The ABC
will begin pre-service programming from 5
am, with the service broadcast live from the
Commemorative Area and Hall of Memory
from 5.30 am.

The event will not be open to the public
but will be broadcast live across Australia
and streamed online. The ABC will make
the broadcast available to other networks
under a host broadcaster arrangement to
enable people to mark Anzac Day safely
and respectfully from home. It will include a
minute’s silence around 6 am so you can pay
your respects wherever you may be.

Director of the Australian War Memorial,
Matt Anderson PSM, said that the situation
surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic makes
this year’s Anzac Day all the more important.

“Anzac Day is traditionally about
acknowledging the resilience and fortitude
demonstrated by the Anzacs at Gallipoli and
the subsequent legacy that was born. Across
the community, people are drawing upon
their own resources to deal with this global
health crisis,” Mr Anderson said.

“It is vital that we have the opportunity
to take time to pause and reflect on Anzac
Day, if not as some brief respite from the
overwhelming nature of the pandemic, but
because it’s what we do.

“Anzac Day happens every year and
it will happen in 2020, albeit in different
circumstances. We are resolute in our
commitment to ensuring Australians can
honour the Australian servicemen and
servicewomen who have served in the
past, and recognise those who are currently
serving.”

The commemorative service will be
attended by dignitaries representing the
Commonwealth of Australia, the people of
New Zealand, the Returned and Services
League, and veterans. There will be a
ceremonial piper, didgeridoo player and
bugler among other traditional elements.

A special pre-recorded Last Post
Ceremony will be posted to the Memorial’s
digital platforms at 4.55 pm on Anzac Day.
The ceremony will feature the story of
Private Thomas Anderson Whyte of the 10th
Battalion AIF who was killed during the
landing at Gallipoli in 1915, read by Sergeant
Shelby Powell of the Royal Australian Air
Force.
ANZAC Appeal
Although people cannot buy badges from veterans this year, donations to the annual appeal can be made online via a secure and easy to use donation website, anzacappeal.com.au.

While there is no face to face selling of
badges this year by Sub-branches, badges
are available for purchase from Woolworths
from 15 April at the service desks.

innovative-time.title: Innovative time for local businesses
innovative-time.abstract:
While COVID-19 has made these past
few weeks a challenging time for local
businesses, especially those in the
hospitality sector, it has also prompted
some new ways of working in a bid to
keep the operation afloat.

pars:
While COVID-19 has made these past
few weeks a challenging time for local
businesses, especially those in the
hospitality sector, it has also prompted
some new ways of working in a bid to
keep the operation afloat.

With restrictions on ‘sitting in’ for meals
at the Motofinish Cafe in Rushworth, owner
Fiona is one of many who have adapted
their service to off-site dining.

The Motofinish menu is now not only
available for takeaway, but it can also be
accessed in a number of different ways.
Customers are welcome to visit the shop
(socially distancing of course!) and choose
from the variety of meals at the counter.
Or, especially for the regulars who know
exactly what they want, the order can be
ordered by phone and picked up at the
kerbside (without ever leaving your car) or
even delivered right to the front door.

With contactless payment made easy
with the portable EFTPOS device, all is
in place for safe and easy meals when the
novelty of ‘isolation cooking’ has worn off!

wicked-community.title: Living in a ‘WICKED’ community
wicked-community.abstract:
Campaspe Shire Council is calling on the community to provide feedback on waste and
the environment through the annual WickED (Waste in Campaspe – know, educate, do)
survey.

pars:
Campaspe Shire Council is calling on the community to provide feedback on waste and
the environment through the annual WickED (Waste in Campaspe – know, educate, do)
survey.

Regulatory and Community Services
General Manager, Paul McKenzie said
Council is collecting data on community
perception and behaviour relating to waste
and the environment.

“A central component of Council’s
waste education program, the survey will
provide valuable information on residents’
knowledge, attitudes and behaviours in
relation to the environment and waste
management practices in Campaspe,” Mr
McKenzie said.

“Survey results will guide the direction
of the WickED program over the next 12
months.”

WickED informs and educates, shaping
positive attitude and behaviour change in
waste reduction, and the survey provides
insight into the impact the program is having
on the community.

The survey seeks feedback on the use of
Council’s eight transfer stations, kerbside
collection, illegal dumping and what
goes in what bins. It provides consistent
baseline data to help with identifying waste
education priorities as well as the planning,
coordination, implementation and evaluation
of the program year on year.

“It is reassuring to learn that over time,
results from the WICKED survey have shown
a considerable shift in peoples’ attitudes and
behaviour towards waste reduction and the
health of the environment,” Mr McKenzie
said.

Over the past six years, there has been
a positive shift towards environmentally
friendly behaviours including:

• 81% of respondents within the shire use a transfer station
  • 94% of respondents use their own bags when shopping (66% increase)
  • 78% of respondents use recycling bins in public areas (12% increase)
  • 81% of respondents are concerned for the environment
  • More than 7,400 properties across the shire have now opted for a food and garden waste bin, reducing the amount of waste going to landfill

By completing the survey, respondents
will go in the draw to win prizes including an
Apple IPad valued at $530.

The WickED survey is open to all
Campaspe Shire and Moama residents,
groups, businesses and schools, and can be
accessed via Council’s website. The online
survey closes Monday, 1 June.

quiet-achievements.title: Quiet achievements at Community House
quiet-achievements.abstract:
As the COVID-19 Pandemic rolls on, Rushworth Community House remains closed to members of the public. However, individual
volunteers have kept the House “ticking over” for the last few weeks, and look likely to continue doing so for the foreseeable future.
This edition of the Waranga News highlights a couple of special activities that will prove valuable when the current restrictions are
eased or lifted.

pars:
As the COVID-19 Pandemic rolls on, Rushworth Community House remains closed to members of the public. However, individual
volunteers have kept the House “ticking over” for the last few weeks, and look likely to continue doing so for the foreseeable future.
This edition of the Waranga News highlights a couple of special activities that will prove valuable when the current restrictions are
eased or lifted.

Rushworth Community Garden holds a
special place in the hearts and minds of many
local people. At this time of year, the garden
looks, feels and smells wonderful.

Wednesdays have traditionally been
the day when community gardeners gather
together to work on their masterpiece, but
with current social distancing laws, such
assemblies are prohibited. Nevertheless, the
garden still needs lots of maintenance and
volunteers are coming in solo each day to
water the plants, attend to the worm farm and
to remove weeds before they can spread.
No buns in the oven

The loneliest object in the Community
Garden has to be its hugely popular Pizza
Oven, which produces sensational pizzas
using vegetable, herbs and spices fresh from
the Garden. A lot of local people are really
looking forward to its next “performance”!
Behind closed doors

Meanwhile, back inside the Community
House, upgrading of its extensive computer
facilities is nearing completion, with only a
few multi-person tasks still outstanding.

Importantly, all computers at the
House now use Microsoft’s Windows 10
Professional operating system, together
with wireless keyboards and mice and the
standardisation will have major benefits
when the House’s many computing activities
(Computer Classes, WebDotWiz, Genealogy)
resume and can be enjoyed with workstation
commonality and user confidence.

Some workstations have now been fitted
with ultra-modern Hewlett Packard “All-In-
One” computers that are a delight to use.

Slightly older desktop units have been
upgraded with additional memory and
other enhancements that have dramatically
improved their performance.

Special PCs have also been built for the
rugged environs of the Mens’ Shed and the Art
Depot, both of which occupy space in the old
Shire of Campaspe maintenance area. These
machines are recycled and re-engineered
IBM desktops that are built tough! (below).

Tests soon revealed that the House’s
recent WiFi service High Street enhancement
still did not cover the Art Depot or Mens
Shed, so microwave links were installed to
ensure that both the Shed and the Depot could
use the powerful RCH computer network.

Remember that members of the public
can use the Community House WiFi from
their cars or nearby houses. Though no public
use of the internal machines is currently
permitted, the WiFi service remains in
operation.

we-can-still-eat-ice-cream.title: Hard times - but we can still eat ice cream!
we-can-still-eat-ice-cream.abstract:
The Cottage Ice Cream Shop has become a well-known and popular go-to venue for residents and visitors to Rushworth.
This April should be party time as owners Michelle and Stewart celebrate its 10th birthday - but, alas, the celebrations
must wait! Still, it’s with some relief that we see the business remains one of the bright spots in our quiet town at the
moment.

pars:
The Cottage Ice Cream Shop has become a well-known and popular go-to venue for residents and visitors to Rushworth.
This April should be party time as owners Michelle and Stewart celebrate its 10th birthday - but, alas, the celebrations
must wait! Still, it’s with some relief that we see the business remains one of the bright spots in our quiet town at the
moment.

We asked Michelle how she felt after ten years serving
ice cream to (very appreciative) children and adults
each day.

“From a very slow beginning and being able to withstand
all the trials that have come with starting a small business,
we can now sit back and reflect on what has become our
new life and home.,” she said.

“Flicking back through my Journal (yes I actually kept
it) has brought back a lot of memories. I ran the business
virtually on my own for the first 12 months before Stewart
moved up here permanently. I will admit that I was a little
bit terrified at the time as I did not know the town or anyone
here.

“Now that we have reached our 10th birthday we are so
happy we made the decision to make Rushworth our home.
We love our town and the people who live here.

“Thank you to all our wonderful customers who have
supported our shop over the last 10 years,” she added.
Congratulations Cottage Ice Cream Shoppe!

colbo-colour.title: Colbo Colour
colbo-colour.abstract: Mayor Adrian Weston recently called into the viewing area at the Colbinabbin Silo Art site to check on the progress of the project with Committee members.

pars: Mayor Adrian Weston recently called into the viewing area at the Colbinabbin Silo Art site to check on the progress of the project with Committee members. With the central concrete R Class Locomotive painting almost complete, artist Tim Bowtell will make a start on one of the metal silos this week. In a few days the next subject matter will be revealed - you can follow along on Facebook for a daily artwork update and guess the emerging theme! Pictured in front of the almost completed artwork are Barry Dawson, Frank Stewart, Adrian Weston, Mary Ann Morgan, Sadie Vale and Guy Rathjen.

events-cancelled.title: Events cancelled due to COVID-19
events-cancelled.abstract: Readers will be aware of the event restrictions put in place in an effort to control the spread of the COVID-19 virus. All events with an attendance of 500 or more people have been either cancelled or postponed until further notice. Many smaller events have been cancelled or postponed at the discretion of their organisers. Because COVID-19 is a new virus there are many unknowns, the least of these unknowns is when postponed events will eventually be held.

pars: Readers will be aware of the event restrictions put in place in an effort to control the spread of the COVID-19 virus.
